      • asyncAbort

      • abort

        public static void abort(@Nullable
                         Abortable abortable,
                         boolean swallowIOException)
                  throws IOException
        Aborts a Abortable, with control over whether an IOException may be thrown. This is primarily useful in a finally block, where a thrown exception needs to be logged but not propagated (otherwise the original exception will be lost).

        If swallowIOException is true then we never throw IOException but merely log it.

        Example: 

           

   public void abortStreamNicely() throws IOException {
      SomeStream stream = new SomeStream("foo");
      try {
          // ... code which does something with the stream ...
      } catch (IOException ioe) {
          // If an exception occurs, we might abort the stream.
          Abortables.abort(stream, true);
      }
   }
        Parameters:
        abortable - the Abortable object to be aborted, or null, in which case this method does nothing.
        swallowIOException - if true, don't propagate IO exceptions thrown by the abort methods
        Throws:
        IOException - if swallowIOException is false and abort throws an IOException

      • abort

        public static void abort(@Nullable
                         AsyncAbortable abortable,
                         boolean swallowIOException)
                  throws IOException
        Abort async abortable.
        Parameters:
        abortable - the AsyncAbortable object to be aborted, or null, in which case this method does nothing.
        swallowIOException - if true, don't propagate IO exceptions thrown by the abort methods
        Throws:
        IOException - if swallowIOException is false and abort throws an IOException
        See Also:
        abort(Abortable, boolean)

      • abortQuietly

        public static void abortQuietly(@Nullable
                                Abortable abortable)
        Aborts the given abortable, logging any IOException that's thrown rather than propagating it.

        While it's not safe in the general case to ignore exceptions that are thrown when aborting an I/O resource, it should generally be safe in the case of a resource that's being used only for reading.

        Parameters:
        abortable - the Abortable to be closed, or null in which case this method does nothing.

      • abortQuietly

        public static void abortQuietly(@Nullable
                                AsyncAbortable abortable)
        Aborts the given abortable, logging any IOException that's thrown rather than propagating it.

        While it's not safe in the general case to ignore exceptions that are thrown when aborting an I/O resource, it should generally be safe in the case of a resource that's being used only for reading.

        Parameters:
        abortable - the AsyncAbortable to be closed, or null in which case this method does nothing.

      • abortSequence

        public static CompletableFuture<Void> abortSequence(ExecutorService executorService,
                                                    AsyncAbortable... abortables)
        Abort the abortables in sequence.
        Parameters:
        executorService - executor service to execute
        abortables - abortables to abort
        Returns:
        future represents the abort future
